2. A 27-year-old female presents to psychiatry with sudden onset of visual hallucinations, vivid nightmares, and severe anxiety lasting one week. She recently began taking high doses of isoniazid for latent tuberculosis after a positive PPD test. Family members report that she has become increasingly withdrawn and paranoid, accusing them of poisoning her food. She denies any prior psychiatric history. On examination, she is alert but visibly distressed, exhibiting pressured speech and persecutory delusions. Vital signs are stable, and neurological examination is normal. Laboratory tests, including liver function and serum drug levels, are within normal limits, and a brain MRI shows no abnormalities. The clinical picture suggests a drug-induced mental disorder due to isoniazid neurotoxicity, leading to initiation of vitamin B6 supplementation and gradual withdrawal of the causative agent.
